dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Five years. That's the average length of an advanced-economy recession, according to this piece.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Five years. That's the average length of an advanced-economy recession, according to this piece.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Lets bear in mind that a typical advanced-economy recession lasts only a year or so, whereas fiscal policy, even in the best of circumstances, invariably takes at least a few months just to be enacted.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and it points out that fiscal policy takes at least a year just to be enacted, even in the best circumstances. That's a huge lag, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and it points out that fiscal policy takes at least a year just to be enacted, even in the best circumstances. That's a huge lag, right?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Lets bear in mind that a typical advanced-economy recession lasts only a year or so, whereas fiscal policy, even in the best of circumstances, invariably takes at least a few months just to be enacted.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And then you've got places like Switzerland with 8.6 million people where there's actually consensus to raise spending as a share of GDP—some of which could be cut in a downturn.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And then you've got places like Switzerland with eight point six million people where there's actually consensus to raise spending as a share of G D P-some of which could be cut in a downturn.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In some small economies for example, Denmark (with 5.8 million people) there is a broad social consensus to raise fiscal spending as a share of GDP. Some of this spending could easily be brought forward in a recession.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But then you look at the UK and France, and there's no such agreement at all. Even if both sides wanted smaller government, their priorities would clash completely.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But then you look at the U K and France, and there's no such agreement at all. Even if both sides wanted smaller government, their priorities would clash completely.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In many other countries, however, notably the US and Germany, there is no such agreement. Even if progressives and conservatives both wanted to expand the government, their priorities would be vastly different.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, like Democrats might push for new social programs, while Republicans would probably want more defense or border spending instead.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, like Democrats might push for new social programs, while Republicans would probably want more defense or border spending instead.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the US, Democrats might favor new social programs to reduce inequality, while Republicans might prefer increased spending on defense or border protection.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And the article brings up Clarence Thomas's Senate confirmation hearings last June as an example of how messy and political fiscal decisions can get.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And the article brings up Clarence Thomas's Senate confirmation hearings last June as an example of how messy and political fiscal decisions can get.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Anyone who watched the US Senate confirmation hearings last September for Supreme Court Justice Brett Kavanaugh cannot seriously believe this group is capable of fine-tuned technocratic fiscal policy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It's not that fiscal stimulus should be totally off the table, but it can't be the first line of defense like some central bankers hope.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's not that fiscal stimulus should be totally off the table, but it can't be the first line of defense like some central bankers hope.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This does not mean that fiscal stimulus should be off the table in the next recession. But it does mean that it cannot be the first line of defense, as altogether too many central bankers are hoping.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: The piece suggests preparing a backlog of high-return infrastructure projects ahead of time—Justin Trudeau actually tried something like that with an infrastructure bank in Canada.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: The piece suggests preparing a backlog of high-return infrastructure projects ahead of time-Justin Trudeau actually tried something like that with an infrastructure bank in Canada.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Former US President Barack Obama wanted to create an infrastructure bank in part for this purpose; tellingly, the idea never got off the ground.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But it never got off the ground, which kinda says it all, doesn't it?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But it never got off the ground, which kinda says it all, doesn't it?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. There's also this idea of strengthening automatic stabilizers, like unemployment benefits—Japan does this way more than the US or Denmark.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. There's also this idea of strengthening automatic stabilizers, like unemployment benefits-Japan does this way more than the U S or Denmark.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Europe, with much higher levels of social insurance and taxation, has correspondingly stronger automatic stabilizers than does the United States or Japan.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But the downside is those come with negative incentive effects from higher taxes and spending. Not so simple.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But the downside is those come with negative incentive effects from higher taxes and spending. Not so simple.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But proponents of higher automatic stabilizers pay too little attention to the negative incentive effects that come with higher government spending and the taxes needed to pay for it.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And then there's the more exotic idea—an independent fiscal council, kind of like a central bank but for budgets. Italy and Spain have weak versions.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then there's the more exotic idea-an independent fiscal council, kind of like a central bank but for budgets. Italy and Spain have weak versions.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Several countries, including Sweden and the United Kingdom, have adopted much watered-down versions of this idea.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But legislatures don't wanna give up power over taxes and spending. Can you blame them?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But legislatures don't wanna give up power over taxes and spending. Can you blame them?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The problem is that elected legislatures dont want to cede power, especially over taxes and spending.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Then there's helicopter money—printing cash and handing it out. But the article calls that fiscal policy in disguise, and it would destroy a central bank's independence.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Then there's helicopter money-printing cash and handing it out. But the article calls that fiscal policy in disguise, and it would destroy a central bank's independence.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Such a policy is, of course, fiscal policy in disguise, and the day any central bank starts doing it heavily is the day it loses any semblance of independence.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So what's left? The author says central banks should look hard at taxing interest on money, positive or negative.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So what's left? The author says central banks should look hard at taxing interest on money, positive or negative.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Central bankers who are serious about preparing for future recessions should be looking hard at proposals for how to pay interest on money, both positive and negative, which is by far the most elegant solution.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's framed as the most elegant solution. Over-relying on fiscal policy just won't cut it this century.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's framed as the most elegant solution. Over-relying on fiscal policy just won't cut it this century.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Central bankers who are serious about preparing for future recessions should be looking hard at proposals for how to pay interest on money, both positive and negative, which is by far the most elegant solution. Over-reliance on countercyclical fiscal policy will not work any better in this century than in it did in the last.

HostB: But then you look at the UK and France, and there's no such agreement at all. Even if both sides wanted smaller government, their priorities would clash completely.

HostA: It’s not that fiscal stimulus should be totally off the table, but it can't be the first line of defense like some central bankers hope.
HostB: The piece suggests preparing a backlog of high-return infrastructure projects ahead of time—Justin Trudeau actually tried something like that with an infrastructure bank in Canada.
HostA: But it never got off the ground, which kinda says it all, doesn't it?
HostB: For sure. There's also this idea of strengthening automatic stabilizers, like unemployment benefits—Japan does this way more than the US or Denmark.

HostA: But legislatures don’t wanna give up power over taxes and spending. Can you blame them?
